I love history, especially history of technical topics. But reading the history of programming languages is a bit like the famous quote about dancing about architecture. If you can't see the syntax of a programming language and the types of problems it was being used to solve it can be very hard to understand what exactly what the languages were doing.

To remedy this I've created this compilation of programming tutorials for old school programming languages. I found that once I could see programs written in say, Lisp and Scheme, it was much easier for me to understand the connection between these two languages. This list covers programming languages from the 1950s up to the mid 1970s. I've left C off the list since it's still in wide use and there are an abundance of learning resources for anyone wanting to learn C.

Special shout out to Derek Banas for creating really fantastic, in-depth tutorials for many of the languages on this list. If anyone knows a good tutorial for ALGOL or SNOBOL hit me up @ajcwebdev on Twitter.

Fortran (1957)

Derek Banas - Fortran Tutorial

Lisp (1958)

Derek Banas - Lisp Tutorial

James Turner - A Brief Introduction to LISP

COBOL (1959)

Fireship - COBOL in 100 seconds

Derek Banas - COBOL Tutorial : Learn COBOL in One Video

Simula (1962)

James Gosling - Simula: A Personal Journey

Dave Thomas - The Legacy of Simula 67

PL/I (1964)

moshix - Exploring the 31 bit IBM PL/I compiler on z/OS - M32

BASIC (1964)

Jay Walker - Learning BASIC Programming

APL (1966)

Bob Spence - APL Demonstration

ISWIM (1966)

Peter Alvaro - I See What You Mean

Pascal (1970)

Hobby .Programming - Pascal Programming Tutorial

Forth (1970)

Bitsrfr - Forth Programming Language

Abraham Moller - Why Forth?

Jack - A Little Bit of Forth

Smalltalk (1972)

Dr. Hrafn Loftsson - Programming Languages: Smalltalk

Dan Ingalls - Alto System Project: Dan Ingalls demonstrates Smalltalk

Dan Ingalls - The Xerox Alto â”‚ Smalltalk-76 Demo

Prolog (1972)

Derek Banas - Prolog Tutorial

ML (1973)

Yaron Minsky - Effective ML

Dr. Hrafn Loftsson - Functional Programming with Standard ML

Scheme (1975)

Andy Balaam - Feel the Cool
